task.title: Selecting objects for hatching
task.shortdesc: A hatch boundary can be defined by means of selecting anobject, for example, a circle or rectangle. You can assign hatching to a single object or several objects at the same time.

context.p: You can add hatching to an area enclosed by selected objects to formthe hatch boundary. The hatch is formed within the enclosed area, not the objects themselves. Once a hatch is created, it will be treated as a single object. And the object being hatched changes along with the hatch boundary if the hatch you create is associative.

step.cmd: Choose Draw > Hatch from the main menu.
From the Hatch and Gradient dialog box, click the Islanddetectionoption, and then choose one of the following islands:

info.p: Normal Areas separated from the outside of the hatched by an odd number of intersections are hatched.
Outer Onlythe outer object andits outer islandare considered for hatching.
Ignore The entire object is considered for hatching, theinnerarea will be ignored.
Normal islands (A), with outer island (B), and with ignoring islands (C).

step.cmd: To keep any new objects that are created for drawing the boundary hatch, select the Retain Boundaries checkbox under Other options. Existing objects are always retained.
In the Boundaries, click Select Objects button.
In the drawing, click the objects to be hatched individually, and then press Enter when done.
In the Hatch and Gradient dialog box, click OK.

To keep any new objects that are created for drawing the boundary hatch, select the Retain Boundaries checkbox under Other options. Existing objects are always retained.
In the Boundaries, click Pick Points button.
In the drawing, click inside the closed perimeter ofa boundary, not on the boundary itself. If desired, continue clicking inside additionallyclosedperimeters.
To complete the selection, press Enter.
In the Hatch and Gradient dialog box, click OK.
